newsitem.title: CHINA: HK's Hang Seng Index closes at all-time high.
newsitem.headline: HK's Hang Seng Index closes at all-time high.

text.p: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed at an all-time high on Thursday, as investors poured into the property sector boosting turnover to its highest level ever.
The Hang Seng Index surged 382.53 points, or 2.39 percent, to close at 16,365.71.
Turnover was HK$28.03 billion, up from HK$21.69 billion on Wednesday and beating the previous record of HK$26.6 billion set on June 20.
"With a chart breakout on record volume there is only one way we are going: 17,000," said James Osborn, sales director at ING Barings.
"This is a very healthy market. The utilities had been strong and there is rotation into the property developers which is spreading out into second and third liners," he said.
The Hang Seng properties sub-index charged well ahead of the blue chip index, rising 4.10 percent to 27,116.55 points.
Analysts said they were encouraged by the response to recent property sales by Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd and Swire Pacific Ltd.
"Property developers had been oversold. People are seeing huge end-user demand in the property market without the speculators and prices are stable. This is the perfect scenario," said Osborn.
Shares in Cheung Kong bounded HK$5.25 to HK$86.00 and Swire Pacific jumped HK$4.00 to HK$73.50.

"People are quite optmistic about a rebound in residential property prices in the next few months. Property stocks tend to move ahead of the prices of residential units," said Henry Lui, research analyst at Mansion House Research.
Alex Wong, technical analyst at Dharmala Securities, said the property stocks may be overbought in the short term and the Hang Seng Index could find resistance at 16,500 points.
"The index has consolidated in a range of 15,630 to 15,880 points recently and broke out of the range yesterday," he said.
"Today we saw some follow-through but we may see some profit-taking over the next one or two days ahead of HSBC's results and U.S. employment data on Friday," he said.
But Osborn saw the Hang Seng Index testing 16,800 points early next week. "We may have a look at 17,000," he said.
HSBC Holdings Plc advanced HK$7.00 to HK$270.00. The banking giant is due to report interim results on Monday.
China Southern Airlines Co Ltd made its market debut and closed at HK$4.875 compared with an issue price of HK$4.70.
CCT Telecom Holdings Ltd soared HK$0.43 to HK$1.78 after it said it would set up joint venture companies in China with a company partly owned by China's Ministry of Electronics Industry.
